entry.title: webkit_unit_tests_v2 very slow on win-asan
entry.content:
https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/ci/win-asan https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/ci/win-asan/29992/overview https://chromium-swarm.appspot.com/task?id=67e5b021b7919710
It's timing out after 60min there on a single shard. Meanwhile the main win10 tester can finish it in ~3min: https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/ci/Win10%20Tests%20x64/88302/overview https://chromium-swarm.appspot.com/task?id=67e5d43f6b502310
So why is the suite so much slower on win-asan?

entry.title: updater: postinstall action needs implementation
Tests are failing: java.lang.RuntimeException: Waited for the root of the view hierarchy to have window focus and not request layout for 10 seconds. If you specified ...

This bug is for all test failures where the primary error message is similiar to the following (ignoring numbers and hexadecimal values): java.lang.RuntimeException: Waited for the root of the view hierarchy to have window focus and not request layout for 10 seconds. If you specified a non default root matcher, it may be picking a root that never takes focus. Root:
Root{application-window-token=android.view.ViewRootImpl$W@9062219, window-token=android.view.ViewRootImpl$W@9062219, has-window-focus=false, layout-params-type=1, layout-params-string={(0,0)(fillxfill) ty=BASE_APPLICATION wanim=0x10302fe
 fl=LAYOUT_IN_SCREEN LAYOUT_INSET_DECOR SPLIT_TOUCH HARDWARE_ACCELERATED DRAWS_SYSTEM_BAR_BACKGROUNDS

 fl=LAYOUT_...

entry.title: View Transition to a pre-rendered page
entry.content:
The flow for navigating to a pre-rendered page is as follows:
- At the beginning of the navigation, all commit deferring conditions are run. These conditions capture the old Document and save the captured state on NavigationRequest. - At the end of these conditions, we check whether the pre-render can be used. This is because the conditions themselves can trigger eviction of the pre-rendered page.
The above is an issue because if pre-render activation fails and the navigation becomes cross-origin when we issue the network request, we'd end up passing the cached VT state to a cross-origin Document. So we must clear the state if pre-render activation fails.

entry.title: updater: yes/no UI dialog is not used.
entry.content: The yes/no dialog, which is present in O3 to prompt the user when closing the UI while an install is in progress is not used in O4.

entry.content:
We wanted to build an automated system to track Loading, Scripting, Rendering & Painting times available in Summary of Performance tab in Devtools. We couldn't find any direct or indirect way to get these numbers via Chrome Devtools Protocol.
Kindly help.

entry.title: CTS: android.text.cts.StaticLayoutGetLineLeftRightTest tests are not run due to spaces in their names
entry.content:
When switching to on-device test listing (from dexdump), some tests were found with spaces in their names, which our test filtering logic does not currently support.
See this run: https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/try/android-12-x64-rel/696751/overview
E.g.: ``` {'class': 'android.text.cts.StaticLayoutGetLineLeftRightTest', 'test': 'testGetLineLeft[leadingMargin 0 align ALIGN_NORMAL dir DIR_LTR]'} {'class': 'android.text.cts.StaticLayoutGetLineLeftRightTest', 'test': 'testGetLineLeft[leadingMargin 0 align ALIGN_NORMAL dir DIR_LTR]'} {'class': 'android.text.cts.StaticLayoutGetLineLeftRightTest', 'test': 'testGetLineRight[leadingMargin 0 align ALIGN_NORMAL dir DIR_LTR]'}, ... ```

entry.title: Trigger Component Update on requestMediaKeySystemAccess
entry.content:
Currently Component Update for the Widevine CDM runs a few minutes after Chrome startup. But based on a recent discussion, it was mentioned that CU can be triggered manually by calling [ComponentUpdateService::MaybeThrottle](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:components/component_updater/component_updater_service.h;l=180-193;drc=0e1cf96ee02deaea99edf9bd588439059245f028). As navigator.requestMediaKeySystemAccess is async, the code could manually trigger a call to CU the first time it is run to make sure that the latest version is available (probably somewhere inside [key_system_support_impl.cc](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/media/key_system_support_impl.cc;l=74;drc=f4a00cc248dd2dc8ec8759fb51620d47b5114090;bpv=1;bpt=1)). This would potentially slow down the response to navigator.requestMediaKeySystemAccess.
This would benefit browsers that do not bundle the CDM, especially for users who download the browser and then try to use it to play protected content right away.
This would only apply to systems where the library can be loaded dynamically (Mac/Windows). On Android Widevine is built into the OS, and on Linux/ChromeOS the library must be loaded when Chrome starts. However, for the latter it may still help, as it would trigger CU so that the latest Widevine CDM is available the next time the user starts the browser.

entry.title: Reenable animation manager browser test for NavigationQueueing
entry.content:
It was disabled for https://issues.chromium.org/issues/326151124#comment1
We will enable this test in a different CL because we want to avoid the entire patch being reverted for a mis-configured test, especially this test is a regression test on a feature that's not shipped yet.

entry.title: Links in "secondary labels" have the wrong font size with CR2023 enabled
entry.content: See attached screenshots; with CR2023 enabled secondary styled text has a smaller font size than regular labels. But StyledLabel always uses the same STYLE_LINK style for links, which can't adjust its size based on surrounding text, resulting in this probably incorrect looking UI.

Nothing, or a list of autocomplete from history when `autocomplete from history` option is checked.

entry.title: PTB: snackbar shouldn't be displayed on the Manage page
entry.content: The snackbar for unblocking a topic should only be displayed on the blocked topics page

entry.title: CTAP2 security keys may return CTAP2_ERR_PIN_POLICY_VIOLATION
entry.content:
> An authenticator MAY impose arbitrary, additional constraints on PINs. If newPin fails to satisfy such additional constraints, the authenticator returns CTAP2_ERR_PIN_POLICY_VIOLATION.
Reportedly we don't handle this when the user tries to set a PIN that the security key doesn't like. [Code search](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:device/fido/auth_token_requester.cc;l=288?q=kCtap2ErrPinPolicyViolation&ss=chromium) agrees.

entry.title: URGENT CRITICAL REGRESSION: Chrome breaks whole system audio
entry.content:
Chrome Version : 122.0.0.0 OS Version : Manjaro Linux URLs (if applicable) : Other browsers tested: Add OK or FAIL, along with the version, after other browsers where you have tested this issue: Safari: Firefox: Edge:
What steps will reproduce the problem? (1) launch Chrome
What is the expected result?
Audio in Chrome should work, and audio outside of Chrome should keep working
What happens instead of that?
The audio of the entire system stops working. Everything goes silent. The only fix is to reboot, then audio works, and as soon as I launch Chrome again, audio stops working again.
Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot if possible.
UserAgentString: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/122.0.0.0 Safari/537.36
For graphics-related bugs, please copy/paste the contents of the about:gpu page at the end of this report.

entry.title: Reason through how to recover from certificate-related compromises
entry.content:
Filing this as a potential far future area to ponder. When there is a certificate-related compromise, we can revoke the certificate and stop future certificate verifications from accepting it. But there is a long path from that to security of the overall website. Some initial thoughts:
A non-exhaustive list of examples:
- There may be active connections authenticated with the compromised certificate - There may be TLS sessions in the session cache, whose secret the attacker knows - The attacker may have poisoned the HTTP cache - The attacker may have poisoned HTTP cookies, localStorage, etc. - The attacker may have stolen HTTP cookies, localStorage, etc. - The attacker may have stolen the user's password - The attacker may have registered a service worker
Ideally, we would have *some* story to recover from these.
At the same time, we keep that state and allow certificates to cycle for a reason:
- The site operator must be able to rotate keys without interrupting their website - The site operator must be able to switch CAs without interrupting their webiste - All the various caches give perf savings that we don't want to regress - We cannot lose user data, so strategies around cookies, localStorage, etc., need to be extra careful - Service workers allow sites to work offline. For any load of a page, arbitrarily into the future, the user may be offline at the time. We cannot interrupt the page.
Squaring these two goals is interesting, and will almost certainly require joint responsibilities across the browser, site operator, and even end users. (Though ideally we avoid the last one as much as possible.) Some initial thoughts:
- The user data issue is pretty bad, so I suspect we need to move poisoned cookie handling to the website: please do not run `eval` on your cookies and localStorage! If you had a key compromise or found a bad cert in the CT logs, you might need to do something there. - Compromised passwords need to be changed and probably require the site to prompt the user to change the password. - Saying "please do not `eval` your HTTP cache isn't viable. At the same time, we don't want to dramatically interrupt the HTTP cache on routine key rotations. Perhaps we trigger a revalidation. However, the etags may have been poisoned too, so maybe we need a new etag that the client guarantees is a SHA-256 hash of the resource? That'll require standardization. - The offline constraint is interesting. Perhaps the goal there should be that we'll notice a bad SW registration if we ever manage to ping the server [and then do... something...], but if we're persistently offline, we're persistently offline

entry.title: Dev channel finch
'beforeinput' event dispatched on the wrong element after an undo/redo
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. Create a webpage with two textarea elements 2. Add 'beforeinput' and 'input' event handlers to the window logging the event target 3. Type something into the 1st textarea 4. Move focus to the 2nd textarea 5. Execute an undo command with Ctrl+Z
# Problem Description Expected behavior: The 'beforeinput' and 'input' events are both dispatched on the 1st textarea element
Actual behavior: The 'beforeinput' event is dispatched on the 2nd textarea, while the 'input' event is dispatched on the 1st textarea element
'beforeinput' events should be dispatched on the element that is about to be modified and not the element where the undo command was executed.
# Additional Comments The bug is also present on <input> elements and elements with the contenteditable attribute. The same wrong behavior can be observed when executing redo commands as well.
# Summary 'beforeinput' event dispatched on the wrong element after an undo/redo
# Custom Questions #### Which component does this fall under? Not sure - I don't know
#### Does this work in other browsers? Yes - This is just a Chrome problem
# Additional Data Category: API \ Chrome Channel: Stable \ Regression: No
